pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 905, 240]]<|/det|>
0625/13 May/June 2012 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 250, 588, 292]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 313, 386, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 344, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 600, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 890, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 890, 446]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 890, 461]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 474, 555, 490]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 630, 91]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical can is rolled along the ruler shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 101, 875, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 320, 267]]<|/det|>
The can rolls over twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 594, 297]]<|/det|>
What is the circumference (distance all round) of the can?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 705, 323]]<|/det|>
A 13cm B 14cm C 26cm D 28cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 351, 96, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 452, 368]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is measured in newtons?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 217, 396]]<|/det|>
A density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 407, 215, 422]]<|/det|>
B energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 228, 448]]<|/det|>
C pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 212, 474]]<|/det|>
D weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 503, 96, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 503, 740, 520]]<|/det|>
In a race, a car travels 60 times around a 3.6km track. This takes 2.4 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 533, 433, 550]]<|/det|>
What is the average speed of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 561, 735, 578]]<|/det|>
A 1.5km/h B 90km/h C 144km/h D 216km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 599, 90]]<|/det|>
A car is moving downhill along a road at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 524, 120]]<|/det|>
Which graph is the speed/time graph for the car?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 129, 811, 469]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 498, 94, 517]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 498, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a handle with three forces, each 100 N, applied to it. The handle is free to move.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 540, 616, 720]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 732, 497, 749]]<|/det|>
What is the effect of the forces on the handle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 134, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 434, 777]]<|/det|>
The handle will move downwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 787, 364, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 365, 802]]<|/det|>
The handle will not move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 813, 529, 829]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 812, 529, 829]]<|/det|>
The handle will turn anticlockwise (to the left).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 839, 134, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 839, 510, 856]]<|/det|>
The handle will turn clockwise (to the right).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 562, 90]]<|/det|>
A stone has a volume of \(0.50 \text{cm}^3\) and a mass of \(2.0 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 390, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 248, 149]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 157, 238, 174]]<|/det|>
B \(1.5g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 182, 238, 199]]<|/det|>
C \(2.5g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 208, 238, 225]]<|/det|>
D \(4.0g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 253, 94, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 777, 271]]<|/det|>
Passengers are **not** allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 281, 675, 414]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 220, 444]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 560, 473]]<|/det|>
A They would cause the bus to become less stable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 482, 485, 498]]<|/det|>
B They would cause the bus to slow down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 508, 566, 524]]<|/det|>
C They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 534, 548, 550]]<|/det|>
D They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 578, 94, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 918, 610]]<|/det|>
A geologist places a small rock on the left-hand pan of a balance. The two pans are level as shown when masses with a total weight of \(23 \text{N}\) are placed on the right-hand pan.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 416, 625]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of 1.0kg to be 10N.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 635, 815, 808]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 820, 413, 836]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of the small rock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 847, 710, 864]]<|/det|>
A \(0.023kg\) B \(2.3kg\) C \(23kg\) D \(230kg\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
An object on a thread is swinging between X and Z, as shown in the diagram. It is moving at X and at Z.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 116, 700, 350]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 361, 744, 378]]<|/det|>
An incomplete word equation about the energy of the object is shown below.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 390, 825, 421]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy = kinetic energy + ......... energy + energy losses at X at Y at Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 645, 452]]<|/det|>
Which form of energy is needed to complete the word equation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 230, 480]]<|/det|>
<pre>A chemical

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 332, 505]]<|/det|>
<pre>B gravitational potential

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 516, 218, 530]]<|/det|>
<pre>C internal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 542, 202, 556]]<|/det|>
<pre>D strain

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 586, 107, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 919, 618]]<|/det|>
Which pair contains only physical quantities that vary with temperature and so could be used in making a thermometer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 544, 645]]<|/det|>
<pre>A activity of a radioactive source, volume of a gas

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 440, 671]]<|/det|>
<pre>B mass of a liquid, volume of a liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 537, 697]]<|/det|>
<pre>C activity of a radioactive source, mass of a solid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 440, 723]]<|/det|>
<pre>D volume of a gas, volume of a liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 752, 107, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 752, 810, 768]]<|/det|>
The molecules of a substance become more closely packed and move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 781, 425, 797]]<|/det|>
What is happening to the substance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 810, 480, 825]]<|/det|>
<pre>A A gas is being heated and compressed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 836, 480, 851]]<|/det|>
<pre>B A gas is being heated and is expanding.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 862, 299, 877]]<|/det|>
<pre>C A liquid is boiling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 888, 514, 903]]<|/det|>
<pre>D A liquid is evaporating at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 623, 90]]<|/det|>
Why does convection take place in a liquid when it is heated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 460, 117]]<|/det|>
A Liquids expand when they are heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 633, 144]]<|/det|>
B Liquids start to bubble when they get close to boiling point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 590, 170]]<|/det|>
C Molecules in the liquid expand when they are heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 660, 195]]<|/det|>
D Molecules near to the surface of the liquid escape into the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 107, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 620, 240]]<|/det|>
In which pair of energy sources are both sources renewable?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 250, 267]]<|/det|>
A oil and coal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 250, 293]]<|/det|>
B oil and tidal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 325, 319]]<|/det|>
C tidal and geothermal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 350, 345]]<|/det|>
D tidal and nuclear fission

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 374, 107, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 895, 406]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a mercury manometer used to measure the pressure of gas in a container. Atmospheric pressure is 76 cm of mercury.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 422, 800, 628]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 641, 387, 657]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure of the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 300, 684]]<|/det|>
A 56 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 300, 710]]<|/det|>
B 68 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 721, 300, 736]]<|/det|>
C 84 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 747, 300, 762]]<|/det|>
D 96 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 791, 107, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 791, 578, 808]]<|/det|>
Which statement is explained by reference to pressure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 820, 542, 836]]<|/det|>
A Objects with greater mass have greater weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 846, 744, 862]]<|/det|>
B One kilogram of water occupies more volume than one kilogram of lead.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 872, 531, 888]]<|/det|>
C Spikes on running-shoes sink into the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 898, 605, 914]]<|/det|>
D Water cooled to a low enough temperature turns to ice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 816, 91]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is observed when looking at smoke particles in air using a microscope

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 562, 120]]<|/det|>
What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 140, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 490, 148]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 148, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 158, 650, 175]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 700, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 180, 700, 198]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 527, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 209, 527, 225]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles hit the walls of the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole of the washer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 297, 772, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 392, 536, 409]]<|/det|>
How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 480, 437]]<|/det|>
<pre>A Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 770, 464]]<|/det|>
<pre>B Cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 474, 495, 490]]<|/det|>
<pre>C Heat the rod and then place it in the hole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 541, 516]]<|/det|>
<pre>D Heat the washer and then place it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 543, 107, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 908, 560]]<|/det|>
A heater supplies 80 J of energy to a block of metal. The temperature of the block rises by \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 710, 591]]<|/det|>
What happens to the block of metal when its temperature falls by \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 603, 465, 619]]<|/det|>
<pre>A Its internal energy decreases by 40 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 475, 645]]<|/det|>
<pre>B Its internal energy decreases by 160 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 456, 672]]<|/det|>
<pre>C Its internal energy increases by 40 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 465, 698]]<|/det|>
<pre>D Its internal energy increases by 160 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 809, 107]]<|/det|>
Two plastic cups are placed one inside the other. Hot water is poured into the inner is put on top, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 114, 660, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 272, 349, 289]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 140, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 300, 610, 318]]<|/det|>
Heat loss by radiation is prevented by the small air gap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 141, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 544, 345]]<|/det|>
No heat passes through the sides of either cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 141, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 354, 714, 371]]<|/det|>
The bench is heated by convection from the bottom of the outer cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 141, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 380, 560, 397]]<|/det|>
The lid is used to reduce heat loss by convection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 106, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 107]]<|/det|>
The diagrams represent the waves produced by four sources of sound. The scales for all the diagrams.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 455, 135]]<|/det|>
Which sound has the highest frequency?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 631, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 631, 435]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 479, 631, 545]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 631, 700]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 727, 91]]<|/det|> A student draws three rays of light from point P through a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 542, 120]]<|/det|> Each point labelled F is a principal focus of the lens. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 128, 816, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 437, 369]]<|/det|> Which of the rays are drawn correctly? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 240, 397]]<|/det|> **A** ray Y only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 407, 240, 423]]<|/det|> **B** ray Z only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 285, 449]]<|/det|> **C** ray X and ray Y <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 285, 475]]<|/det|> **D** ray X and ray Z <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 503, 107, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 503, 500, 520]]<|/det|> The image formed by a plane mirror is upright. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 529, 779, 727]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 743, 517, 759]]<|/det|> What are the other characteristics of the image? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 764, 914]]<|/det|>
laterally inverted
(left to right)		magnified
(larger than the object)		virtual
Anoyesyes
Byesnono
Cyesnoyes
Dyesyesno

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 613, 90]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes light waves and radio waves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 102, 549, 228]]<|/det|>
light wavesradio waves
Alongitudinallongitudinal
Blongitudinaltransverse
Ctransverselongitudinal
Dtransversetransverse
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 257, 107, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 377, 274]]<|/det|> What is the unit of wavelength? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 200, 302]]<|/det|> A hertz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 203, 328]]<|/det|> B metre <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 339, 300, 355]]<|/det|> C metre per second <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 216, 380]]<|/det|> D second <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 409, 107, 427]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 920, 441]]<|/det|> A girl stands at a distance from a large building. She claps her hands and a short time later hears an echo. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 656, 470]]<|/det|> Why is an echo produced when the sound waves hit the building? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 482, 420, 498]]<|/det|> A The sound waves are absorbed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 509, 420, 524]]<|/det|> B The sound waves are diffracted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 415, 550]]<|/det|> C The sound waves are reflected. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 561, 415, 576]]<|/det|> D The sound waves are refracted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 805, 107]]<|/det|> The diagram shows water waves passing through a gap in a harbour wall. The round the wall and reach a small boat in the harbour. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[302, 115, 690, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 318, 920, 352]]<|/det|> What is the name of this curving effect, and how can the gap be changed so that the waves are less likely to reach the boat? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 363, 643, 492]]<|/det|>
name of effectchange to the gap
Adiffractionmake the gap slightly bigger
Bdiffractionmake the gap slightly smaller
Crefractionmake the gap slightly bigger
Drefractionmake the gap slightly smaller
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 518, 107, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 518, 748, 536]]<|/det|> A thermistor is used in a circuit to control a piece of equipment automatically. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 547, 410, 564]]<|/det|> What might this circuit be used for? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 530, 593]]<|/det|> **A** lighting an electric lamp as it becomes darker <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 540, 619]]<|/det|> **B** ringing an alarm bell if a locked door is opened <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 629, 600, 645]]<|/det|> **C** switching on a water heater at a pre-determined time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 655, 615, 672]]<|/det|> **D** turning on an air conditioner when the temperature rises

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 106, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 803, 91]]<|/det|> A circuit-breaker is designed to protect a circuit which usually carries a current of 2 A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 791, 121]]<|/det|> The time taken to break the circuit depends on the current, as shown in the graph. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 131, 796, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 885, 412]]<|/det|> What happens when the current in the circuit is 2A and what happens when the current 18A? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 881, 553]]<|/det|>
when the current is 2Awhen the current is 18A
Athe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Bthe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit does not break
Cthe circuit does not breakthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Dthe circuit does not breakthe circuit does not break

<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 540, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 380, 117]]<|/det|>
A It attracts ferrous materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 512, 144]]<|/det|>
B It could have only one pole (north or south).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 547, 170]]<|/det|>
C It points in a random direction when suspended.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 406, 195]]<|/det|>
D It repels non-ferrous materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 107, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 604, 241]]<|/det|>
Which procedure may be used to demagnetise a steel bar?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 327, 268]]<|/det|>
A cooling it in a freezer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 391, 294]]<|/det|>
B earthing it with a copper wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 630, 320]]<|/det|>
C placing it in a solenoid carrying a large direct current (d.c.)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 448, 346]]<|/det|>
D striking it repeatedly with a hammer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 453, 662]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 601, 688]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 699, 601, 714]]<|/det|>
D Y moves towards the coil, X moves away from the coil.
